rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Ruskin Colony at Yellow Creek, Tennessee
abstract: Indiana newspaperman Julius Augustus Wayland inaugurated the idea for the Ruskin Cooperative Association in 1881. His dream was realized in 1894 when the Ruskin Cooperative Association (named after English social critic John Ruskin) was established in Tennessee City. The colony soon moved to a site near a large cave on Yellow Creek that still bears the name Ruskin. Wayland led the colony for only a year, and tensions soon developed between those colonists who wanted to apply radical socialist ideals in order to bring about the "coming nation" and those who considered Ruskin a haven for such American concepts as political and economic independence. By 1899, this factionalism had caused the colony to disintegrate. The colony was put into receivership, sparking two years of lawsuits between the opposing groups over ownership and control of the Association. Although a few of the colony's members attempted to reestablish it in Georgia as the Ruskin Commonwealth, these efforts proved unsuccessful.

title: East Tennessee Deaf and Dumb School
abstract: The Tennessee Deaf and Dumb School (whose name changed to the Tennessee School for the Deaf in 1925) was established in Knoxville in 1844. The original campus was the Churchwell House, but the school soon moved to land donated by C.M. McClung near the center of town. After closing during the Civil War, the school expanded quickly during the Reconstruction Era. By 1922, the institution had outgrown its quarters and moved to what had been the Dickinson Estate in South Knoxville. As in previous years, both the campus and its programs expanded quickly. The school continues to serve an important role in Tennessee's educational system today.

abstract: Map of Harder & Co.'s addition to Knoxville, apparently drawn by John H. Shields in 1856. This addition stretches from Ohio Street in the North to the railroad tracks in the South and Spring Street in the East to Elm Street in the West. It borders on Temple's Addition and King's Addition.

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Knoxville City Hall
abstract: View of the front entrance to Knoxville's old City Hall. The building was constructed in 1844 and originally housed the Tennessee School for the Deaf. It served as a makeshift hospital for both Union and Confederate troops during the Civil War but returned to its original purpose when the war ended. It became Knoxville's City Hall in 1924, and continued in this function until 1980. The structure is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
name: University of Tennessee Photographic Center

title: Moore Oil Company
abstract: Calloway A. Moore (1881-1965) operated the Moore Oil Company on Knoxville's North Gay Street between 1923 and 1927. This image shows the store itself, the trolley tracks in front of the store, and banners advertising Marathon Motor Oil.
name: unknown

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: International Court of Flags and the State of Tennessee Amphitheater
abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

title: Tennessee State Capitol Building
abstract: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim - indeed, several astute commentators have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capital had moved to Middle Tennessee. In any case, the building was razed in January of 1927.

title: Appalachian Exposition Main Building
abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Greta Garbo in "A Woman of Affairs"
abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).
name: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer

title: Port of Knoxville Public Terminal
abstract: River traffic has flowed through East Tennessee since the area was settled in the late 18th century. From 1930 to 1933, the TVA made a number of improvements to the river that allowed for a significant increase in the quantity of Knoxville's river trade. The TVA operated Knoxville's Public Terminal (located on Neyland Drive) from 1944 to 1952, when it was leased to private interests. In 1962, the terminal was sold and became a for-hire facility.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: First Methodist Episcopal Church
abstract: The first Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J.B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch and Market Streets. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this church, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H.H. Richardson. The Church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became the First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.

publisher: Published 1991, East Tennessee Historical Society, 500 W. Church Avenue, Knoxville, TN 37902

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: First Baptist Church
abstract: Brothers James and John Moses organized the congregation that would become Knoxville's First Baptist Church in 1843. The church's first permanent house of worship stood on Gay Street and was completed in 1850. The congregation split in 1869, and the dissidents formed Knoxville's Second Baptist Church. The First Baptist Church moved to their second home (made possible in large part by merchant and philanthropist W.W. Woodruff) in 1888. Their current house of worship, located at the corner of Walnut and Main Streets, was completed in 1924 and is still in use today. It was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Gillette Ranch Billiard Room
abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.

abstract: The Knoxville suburb of Fountain City began as a center of religious camp meetings in the 1830s. After the Fountain Head Improvement Company built a three-story hotel in 1886 and the Fountain Head Railroad Company began carrying tourists to the area in 1890, however, it lost its original farming character and became a resort area.

title: Group at Marion Brown's 50th Birthday Party
abstract: Marion Ruth Spies was born in Ohio on January 22, 1905. She worked as a schoolteacher before moving to Hollywood in search of a more exciting life. She married director Clarence L. Brown on November 10, 1947. He had previously been married to Paul (called Polly) Pratt, Ona Maris, and Alice Joyce. Later in life, Marion Brown became one of the major forces behind the Browns' many contributions to the University of Tennessee. Clarence Brown died on August 17, 1987 and Marion Brown followed on May 10, 1993.

title: Post Office and Custom House Building
abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new Post Office was constructed in 1934. The TVA occupied the building until 1976, when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

title: Audience in the Bijou Theater
abstract: The Lamar House Hotel was built in 1817. The Bijou Theatre opened as part of that hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. By 2005, however, the Theater was deteriorating and its owners defaulted on their mortgage. Knoxvillians, including Mayor Bill Haslam, banded together to save the Theater and fundraising and renovation efforts are ongoing. This photograph was taken between Acts II and III of _Little Johnny Jones_ on the Bijou's opening night.

title: Second Presbyterian Church
abstract: The Second Presbyterian Church was organized in 1818 due to a split (brought on by disagreements over doctrine and renting pews) in the First Presbyterian Church's congregation. They built their first church on the west side of Prince (now Market) Street in 1820. The congregation grew quickly and moved to a larger building on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street in 1860. The area around the church grew more congested as Knoxville grew, and the congregation sold their Market Street property and moved to a new building on the corner of Clinch and Walnut in 1905. The congregation eventually outgrew this building as well, and moved to a structure on Kingston Pike in 1957.

title: Chilhowee Park
abstract: Boaters on Chilhowee Park's lake prior to the 1910 Appalachian Exposition. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

title: Interior of the Whittle Springs Hotel
abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Clarence Brown and Rudolph Valentino on the set of "The Eagle"
abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Wonderland Hotel
abstract: The Wonderland Park resort community (including the Wonderland Hotel) was created in Elkmont in 1912 to rival the Appalachian Club's nearby resort area. The Wonderland Park Hotel and its associated buildings became the Wonderland Club in 1914 when they were sold to a group of private investors from Knoxville. Most of these private owners managed to obtain lifetime leases when the Great Smoky Mountains National Park was created. The majority of these leases were eventually converted to 20-year leases that were later extended to expire in 1992. The Wonderland Hotel ceased operations when its lease expired and collapsed in 2005 while debate over what to do with the historic structures standing in Elkmont raged. Although salvage efforts were discussed, the hotel was demolished in late 2006.
name: Thompson, James Edward, 1880-1976

title: First Electric Streetcar to Lake Ottosee
abstract: Although Knoxville's streetcar system was established in 1876, electric streetcars did not arrive until 1890 when W.C. McAdoo Jr. consolidated the existing streetcar lines into the Knoxville Electric Streetcar Company. McAdoo electrified four lines in all: the Lake Ottosee Line, the Park Avenue Line, the Washington Avenue Line, and the Broadway Line. The streetcar in this image was the first to run on the electrified lines.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Myrna Loy in "Wife vs. Secretary"
abstract: "Wife vs. Secretary" tells the story of Van Stanhope (Clark Gable), an industrious magazine publisher who is happily married to Linda (Myrna Loy). Although his secretary, Helen "Whitey" Wilson (Jean Harlow), is in love with him, she respects his marriage and takes pains to ensure that their relationship remains strictly professional. Linda is suspicious, however, especially since her mother (May Robson) frequently suggests that Van is being unfaithful. These suspicions are apparently confirmed when Van takes Whitey on an important business trip to Cuba. Linda is infuriated, but Whitey manages to convince her that her husband has never betrayed her, thus saving their marriage.
name: unknown

subject_topical: Motion picture producers and directors--United States

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Clarence Brown in Childhood
abstract: Clarence Brown was born on May 10, 1890, in Clinton, Massachusetts. He moved with his family to Knoxville, Tennessee as a child and graduated from Knoxville High School in 1905. Brown received a double degree in mechanical and electrical engineering from the University of Tennessee in 1910 and then began a career selling automobiles in Alabama. Fascinated with movies, he moved to New Jersey where he studied with French director Maurice Tourneur at Peerless Studios. There, the pair directed "The Last of the Mohicans" (1920). Brown directed or produced more than fifty widely-acclaimed full length motion pictures and worked with many of the most famous performers in the film industry, including Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Chained" (1934), Spencer Tracy in "Edison the Man" (1940), Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet" (1945), and Gregory Peck in "The Yearling" (1947). At the time of his retirement in 1952, Brown had received six Academy Award nominations for Best Director and won eight Oscars for his films. When he died in 1987, Brown left $12 million to the University of Tennessee. When added to the $1 million donated during his lifetime, the sum made him the largest donor in the university's history.
name: unknown

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Gay Street Viaduct
abstract: The Gay Street Viaduct was constructed in 1919 when the street's north end was raised by 15 feet. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

Today, these stations continue to research numerous topics and provide important contributions to agricultural science in Tennessee and around the world.

subject_topical: Motion picture producers and directors--United States
rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Clarence Brown Plowing with Horses
abstract: In 1926, razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.
name: unknown

title: Clark Gable and Rosalind Russell in "They Met in Bombay"
abstract: "They Met in Bombay" is the story of Gerald Meldrick (Clark Gable) and Anya Von Duren (Rosalind Russell), two jewel thieves intent on stealing a gem from India. After failing independently, they decide to team up. Meldrick intends to let von Duren commit the initial theft and then steal the jewel from her, but she discovers his plans and soon both are fugitives in China. They manage to outwit Inspector Cressney (Matthew Boulton) and mercenary freighter captain Chang (Peter Lorre), but are finally drawn into a pitched battle with invading Japanese forces.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: East Tennessee Hospital for the Insane
abstract: The East Tennessee Hospital for the Insane opened in 1886 with 99 patients transferred from the older Tennessee Lunatic Asylum in Nashville. In 1920, the facility's name was changed to Eastern State Hospital as part of a program to rename all of the asylums in the state. The facility was updated in 1971 after a number of deficiencies were exposed. The hospital's name was changed again, this time incorporating the phrase "Mental Health Institute," in 1977. It continues to operate as a mental health care center today.

title: Directors of the Appalachian Exposition
abstract: The 1910 Appalachian Exposition was held from September 12 to October 12 in Knoxville's Chilhowee Park. The first of its kind in Appalachia, the Fair was intended to demonstrate Southern progress in industry and commerce and to advocate the preservation of the area's natural resources. The fair did not, however, achieve its broader goal%3A to turn Knoxville into a model New South city.

title: Aftermath of the "Million Dollar Fire"
abstract: View of Gay Street after Knoxville's "Million Dollar Fire." This fire, which occurred on April 7, 1897, started in the Hotel Knox and consumed most of the 400 block of Gay Street before being stopped at the Sanford, Chamberlain & Albers Company Building with a firewall. The fire killed three people and a rare white mule (visiting Knoxville with an itinerant circus). The mule's ghost is said to have started a number of small fires in the area since.

Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.
name: Dapprich, Frederic R, 1880-1965

title: Baker-Himel School
abstract: Lewis M.G. Baker and Charles M. Himel established this private school, located on the corner of Highland and 12th Streets, in 1889. It was dedicated to preparing boys for college, and for many years the University of Tennessee and several other schools admitted its graduates without further examination. The school's building was destroyed by fire in 1893 but was replaced by a larger structure later that year. It finally closed in 1913.

title: Clarence Brown Directing "Flesh and the Devil"
abstract: "Flesh and the Devil" tells the story of two Austrian military men, Leo von Harden (John Gilbert) and Ulrich von Eltz (Lars Hanson), who have been friends since childhood. At the beginning of the movie, von Harden meets (and begins an affair with) Felicitas (Greta Garbo). When her husband Count Von Rhaden (Marc MacDermott) discovers them, he challenges von Harden to a duel. von Harden kills the Count, but his superiors send him to Africa as punishment. When he returns, it is to find Felicitas married to von Eltz, who he had asked to take care of her during his absence. von Harden eventually loses control of himself, and the movie ends with a climactic duel between the two former friends.

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Mrs. Jane Kennedy's Home
abstract: Four children playing on the front lawn of Mrs. Jane Kennedy's home. General James White built part of the house itself (the first in Knoxville) in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to proctect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.
name: unknown

title: Donald Crisp and Elizabeth Taylor in "National Velvet"
abstract: "National Velvet" stars Elizabeth Taylor as Velvet Brown, an English girl with a passion for horses who wins the spirited but untrained steed Pie in a town auction. Velvet is determined to win the prestigious Grand National, and jaded jockey Mi Taylor (Mickey Rooney) is hired to train her. Although Velvet's father (Donald Crisp) disapproves, her mother (Anne Revere), recalling her own girlhood ambitions, repeatedly overrules his decisions in favor of their headstrong daughter. Against all odds, Velvet and Pie go on to win the Steeplechase at the Grand National.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Training at Camp Barkley
abstract: The original caption for this image reads "Camp Barkley. Dec 9 1941. Co. K. 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

title: Joan Crawford in "Possessed"
abstract: "Possessed" is the story of Marian Martin (Joan Crawford), a factory girl who moves to Manhattan looking for excitement and hoping to trade her life on the assembly line for one more posh. When she meets lawyer Mark Whitney (Clark Gable), she thinks her dreams have come true%3A he is rich and handsome and can buy her the life she dreams of. Unfortunately, he is already married and his political ambitions would be destroyed by a divorce scandal. Thus, Martin becomes his mistress and poses as his ex-wife. When her small town ex-boyfriend Al Manning (Wallace Ford) asks her to marry him, she turns him down and he exposes Whitney's sordid private life. Martin is forced to defend her relationship with Whitney at an election rally, and her story moves the crowd to tears. Relieved, Whitney proposes to Martin, thus fulfilling her ambitions.
name: unknown

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: The Sunsphere
abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Knoxville Court House
abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Tennessee's first governor, John Sevier, and his wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried on the lawn.

title: Aftermath of the "Million Dollar Fire"
abstract: View of Gay Street after Knoxville's "Million Dollar Fire." This fire, which occurred on April 7, 1897, started in the Hotel Knox and consumed most of the 400 block of Gay Street before being stopped at the Sanford, Chamberlain & Albers Company Building with a firewall. The fire killed three people and a rare white mule (visiting Knoxville with an itinerant circus). The mule's ghost is said to have started a number of small fires in the area since.
name: unknown

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Scene from "The Eagle"
abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Knox County Court House
abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Tennessee's first governor, John Sevier, and his wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried on the lawn.
name: Thompson's Commercial Photographers

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Greta Garbo in "Romance"
abstract: Presented as a series of flashbacks, "Romance" stars Greta Garbo as famous operatic soprano Madame Rita Cavallini. Thomas Armstrong (Gavin Gordon), and aristocratic clergyman, falls in love with Cavallini at a party and the two begin a relationship in spite of his family's disapproval and rumors of her checkered past. Their plans for marriage dissolve when Armstrong discovers that she was previously involved with his uncle, Cornelius 'Corny' Van Tuyl (Lewis Stone). Armstrong denounces her and the two never see each other again. Unfortunately, his story does not dissuade his grandson Harry (Elliott Nugent) from marrying an actress, and Armstrong later reads of Cavallini's death in the newspaper.
name: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Gay Street Bridge
abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Ayres Hall
abstract: Ayres Hall, named for UT president Brown Ayres, was constructed in 1919 to replace decaying Old College, East College, and West College. Although money was raised to preserve Old College (dear to many alumni) it was discovered that its brick, which had been cheaply made, had decayed to the point that it was unsafe to move and the building was razed. Ayres Hall was dedicated in 1921 and has served as the campus's "landmark building" ever since. Chi Omega donated Ayres' first set of chimes in 1950, which rang every quarter hour until they were stolen by vandals in the early 1970s. The Class of 1991 replaced the chimes as their senior gift, thus reviving the tradition of "telling time by Ayres' chimes."
name: Standard Souvenirs and Novelties, Inc.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Will Geer and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust"
abstract: Will Geer (who played Sheriff Hampton) and Juano Hernandez in "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.

title: Hotel Farragut
abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

title: Whittle Springs Hotel
abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

title: Knoxville's First Market House
abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

title: John T. Whitaker and Mary Maverick (Lloyd) Whitaker
abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946. The woman shown with Whitaker is most likely his first wife, Mary Maverick Lloyd (1905-1976), who devoted her life to the cause of world government and citizenship.

title: Chilhowee Park
abstract: Swimmers in Chilhowee Park#x0027;s lake. Visible are the extreme left side of the Liberal Arts Building (constructed for the National Conservation Exposition of 1913) and the lake#x0027;s distinctive walkway. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913. Although it has lost some of its former grandeur, the Park is still a popular recreation area today.

title: Lobby Card for "The Yearling"
abstract: "The Yearling" tells the story of an American family living in Florida shortly after the Civil War. Ezra "Penny" Baxter (Gregory Peck) is a hardworking farmer struggling to support his wife, Orry (Jane Wyman), and single surviving son, Jody (Claude Jarman, Jr.). When Penny is bitten by a rattlesnake, he is forced to kill a doe to obtain the necessary antivenin. Jody begs to keep her orphaned faun, and his father agrees. When the faun becomes a yearling, however, it begins breaking into the garden that the family depends on for both food and money. As a result, Jody is forced to make a heartbreaking choice.
name: Loew's Incorporated

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Fort James White
abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

title: Hubert R. Knickerbocker
abstract: This image most likely shows Hubert Renfro Knickerbocker (1898-1949), who was a prominent foreign correspondent for such newspapers as the New York Evening Post and the Philadelphia Public Ledger. He covered such conflicts as the Italo-Abyssinian War (1935-1936), the Spanish Civil War (1936-1937), and the Sino-Japanese War (1937) before working in Europe during World War II. He also taught journalism at Southern Methodist University (1922-1923) and wrote a number of books.

title: View of Strong Hall (White Avenue Entrance)
abstract: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

abstract: "Anna Karenina" stars Greta Garbo as the sheltered wife of Czarist official Karenin (Basil Rathbone). She is not happy in her marriage, however, and soon falls in love with Count Vronsky (Frederic March). When this affair is discovered, Anna Karenina is cast out of upper-class Russian society and is even prohibited from seeing her son, Sergei (Freddie Bartholomew), whose father tells him that his mother is dead. Anna Karenina follows Vronsky to Venice and later to St. Petersburg, where he deserts her to fight in the Turkish-Serbian War. She is finally driven to suicide, and throws herself under a train.

title: Gillette Ranch Sitting Room
abstract: In 1926, Razor baron King Camp Gillette commissioned Wallace Neff to build him a "paradise on earth" in Southern California. The result was a stunning 25 room mansion built in the Spanish Colonial Revival Style whose beauty supposedly brought Gillette to tears. Gillette died in 1932, and his widow sold the property to prominent film director Clarence Brown in 1935. Brown regularly hosted large parties for well-known Hollywood personalities here, and made several changes to the property, including the addition of a projection room and a small airport. He sold the property to the Claretian Order of the Catholic Church in 1952, which used it as a seminary and noviate. The Claretians subsequently sold to Elizabeth Clair Prophet's Church Universal and Triumphant in 1977, which in turn sold to the Soka University of American in 1986. In 2007, Soka sold the property to the National Park Service, which intends to restore and preserve it.
name: Dapprich, Frederic R, 1880-1965

abstract: Central Methodist Episcopal Church South, designed by Chattanooga architect R.H. Hunt, was dedicated in March of 1927. abstract: Park City High School was built in 1907. For a brief time, it was the largest high school in Knoxville. It later became Park Lowry Grammar School and was closed in 1982. The building was sold to private contractors in the mid 1980s, but was completely razed after being badly damaged by fire in September of 1987.

title: John Whitaker and Unidentified Woman
abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

title: Donald Crisp in "National Velvet"
abstract: "National Velvet" stars Elizabeth Taylor as Velvet Brown, an English girl with a passion for horses who wins the spirited but untrained steed Pie in a town auction. Velvet is determined to win the prestigious Grand National, and jaded jockey Mi Taylor (Mickey Rooney) is hired to train her. Although Velvet's father (Donald Crisp) disapproves, her mother (Anne Revere), recalling her own girlhood ambitions, repeatedly overrules his decisions in favor of their headstrong daughter. Against all odds, Velvet and Pie go on to win the Steeplechase at the Grand National.

title: Clark Gable and Myrna Loy in "Wife vs. Secretary"
abstract: "Wife vs. Secretary" tells the story of Van Stanhope (Clark Gable), an industrious magazine publisher who is happily married to Linda (Myrna Loy). Although his secretary, Helen "Whitey" Wilson (Jean Harlow), is in love with him, she respects his marriage and takes pains to ensure that their relationship remains strictly professional. Linda is suspicious, however, especially since her mother (May Robson) frequently suggests that Van is being unfaithful. These suspicions are apparently confirmed when Van takes Whitey on an important business trip to Cuba. Linda is infuriated, but Whitey manages to convince her that her husband has never betrayed her, thus saving their marriage.

title: Perez Dickinson Home
abstract: Perez Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830, where he quickly became an extremely popular and successful merchant. He had this elegant home at the corner of Main and Locust Streets built in 1831. After his death in 1901, C.B. Atkin bought the house and made several additions, including a front portico in the classic colonial style. The structure was demolished in about 1950.

title: Company Fatigue Detail
abstract: The original caption for this image reads "Company fatigue detail - unloading gravel in company street. March-1941. Camp Barkley, Texas. Co. K 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

title: Entrance to the World's Fair (Red Gate)
abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

title: Whittle Springs Hotel
abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cusine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

title: Gay Street Viaduct
abstract: This bridge was built in 1876 in order to allow traffic on Gay Street to travel over the railroad tracks. It was replaced in 1919 when Gay Street's northern end was raised by 15 feet and a viaduct was constructed. A number of shops moved to locations under the new viaduct, where they prospered for many years. Unfortunately, the structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November of 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006, which remains in use today.

The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. title: Mary Olivia Rawls (Mills) Hoskins
abstract: Mary Olivia Rawls was born to William and Susan (Dickason) Rawls on a plantation near Commerce Landing, Mississippi on January 8, 1842. Her parents died shortly after she was born, and she was adopted by Captain John Mills and his wife. The family moved to East Tennessee, where Mary Mills attended Dr. Park's seminary in Rogersville and graduated from the East Tennessee Female Institute. She married William Patton Hoskins (1838-1902) on September 26, 1860, and the couple had seven children: Leila Susan, Nellie Temple, James Dickason, Lynn Wood, Horace Mills, Bessie Olivia, and Mary Margaret. Mary Rawls Mills Hoskins died in 1917 in Knoxville, Tennessee.

title: Clarence Brown on the Set of "Deep Waters"
abstract: The film "Deep Waters," directed by Clarence Brown's mentor Maurice Tourneur, was adapted from the book "Caleb West: Master Diver" by Francis H. Smith and released in 1920. In the movie, Henry Sanford (Henry Woodward) is building a lighthouse at Keyport when he falls in love with Kate Leroy (Florence Deshon). Unfortunately, she is already married to wealthy Morgan Leroy (Jack McDonald). Simultaneously, Betty (Barbara Bedford), wife of master diver Caleb West (Broerkin Christians), attracts the attention of Bill Lacey (John Gilbert), who works with her husband. When Lacey is injured, Betty takes care of him and eventually agrees to run away with him. She soon repents of her rash action, but her husband will not take her back. Later, Lacey's ship is wrecked near the new lighthouse and West makes a dive to recover his body. Upon returning to the surface, he discovers that Betty has been operating his air pump, and the two reconcile.
name: unknown

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Gay Street Bridge
abstract: The Union Army built Knoxville's first bridge across the Tennessee River during the Civil War. This structure was washed away in 1867 and subsequently replaced by a toll bridge. A tornado destroyed this span in 1875, and a fourth bridge was constructed in 1880. This structure lasted until 1898, when it was replaced by a modern and much-admired steel bridge.

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Lawson McGhee Library
abstract: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established the Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay and Vine was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market and Commerce in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Corporal Thomas J. Hawley Jr.
abstract: The original caption for this image reads "Corp. Hawley. Co. K 158th Inf. 45th Div. Fort Sill Okla. Sept 1940-March 1941." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.

title: Ewell Farm (Spring Hill, Tennessee)
abstract: George Campbell Brown was born to Lizinka Campbell and James Percy Brown on November 27, 1840. He served in the Confederate Army during the Civil War and later operated his family's farm, called Ewell Farm, in Spring Hill (Maury County) Tennessee. Under his management, the farm expanded into one of the region's most prosperous plantations. After his death on July 30, 1893, his son Lucius Polk Brown took over the thriving family business.

abstract: View of houses on Knoxville's Park Avenue. These houses were part of Welles' Central District, which she reports is characterized by "poverty, filth and squalor ... in many sections" although conditions had improved in recent years. Most of the people who live in the area are "poor whites of unassorted varieties of occupations."

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Berry Funeral Home
abstract: Ralph Lawson Berry founded the Ralph L. Berry Funeral Home on September 20, 1928. His son, Fred O. Berry Sr., joined him in the business in 1934, but problems among the stockholders forced both to resign in 1936. In 1937, Ralph Berry, Fred Berry, and Edward Weigel founded the Berry Funeral Home on South Gay Street. In 1948, the business expanded when the Berry Funeral Home purchased and remodeled a structure (shown here) on Chapman Highway. A number of other major expansions were made in later years (including a merger with SCI Funeral Services of Tennessee) and Berry Funeral Home continues to operate as one of the most prestigious mortuary services in Tennessee.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Knoxville High School
abstract: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

abstract: Unidentified man, Larkin Brown, and Clarence Brown sitting on "Umbrella Rock" in Point Park (located on Lookout Mountain near Chattanooga, Tennessee). A plaque near them commemorates the Battle of Wauhatchie. This battle, fought in southern Tennessee and northern Georgia on October 28-29, 1863, was one of the most significant night engagements of the Civil War.

title: Post Office and Custom House Building
abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new Post Office was constructed in 1934. The TVA occupied the building until 1976, when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

title: Clarence Brown and Helen Hayes on the Set of "Night Flight"
abstract: Lionel Barrymore stars in "Night Flight" as Riviere, a dedicated pilot contracted to deliver mail. He is determined to keep to his schedule, even if it endangers his pilots. Among these airmen is Jules (Clark Gable) who does not respect Riviere but does his best to fulfill his expectations. After he is killed, Riviere has to tell his widow (Helen Hayes) that he is dead. Riviere does not, however, reduce his demands, even after he loses another pilot. Instead, he insists that more men be called up to ensure that the mail is delivered on time.

title: Portrait of John T. Whitaker
abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Fort James White
abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design intended to protect against Indians. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970, when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville. It currently stands near the Knoxville Coliseum and is one of the most visited historical sites in the city.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Residences on Kingston Pike
abstract: Charles McClung built Kingston Pike in 1792. He also commissioned the first home to be built along the Pike, which he named "Statesview." Over the years, other wealthy Knoxvillians built more homes along the road, including Drury P. Armstrong's "Crescent Bend" (1832), Robert H. Armstrong's "Bleak House" (1856), and J.E. Lutz's "Westwood" (1890). Although the Pike has been heavily developed during the 20th century, some portions retain their original residential character.

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: World's Fair Entrance (Red Gate) and Neyland Stadium
abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

title: Brown using his own camera on the set of "Idiot's Delight"
abstract: Clarence Brown using his own camera on the set of "Idiot's Delight." The movie (based on the play of the same name by Robert Sherwood) stars Clark Gable as entertainer Harry Van. Van and his partner Madame Zuleika (Laura Hope Crews) have developed a "psychic" act in which Van gives the blindfolded Zuleika cues that allow her to accurately describe a member of the audience. Zuleika becomes so drunk, however, that she confuses her prompts (even when reminded loudly from offstage by Irene Fellara) and the couple are booed off stage. Years later, Van and Fellara (Norma Shearer) meet in a hotel in Geneva and a series of antics ensue. The pair's shallow lives provide a vivid counterpoint to a world on the brink of war.

title: Mary Olivia Rawls (Mills) Hoskins and Betsey Olivia Beeler
abstract: Mary Olivia Rawls was born to William and Susan (Dickason) Rawls on a plantation near Commerce Landing, Mississippi on January 8, 1842. Her parents died shortly after she was born, and she was adopted by Captain John Mills and his wife. The family moved to East Tennessee, where Mary Mills attended Dr. Park's seminary in Rogersville and graduated from the East Tennessee Female Institute. She married William Patton Hoskins (1838-1902) on September 26, 1860, and the couple had seven children: Leila Susan, Nellie Temple, James Dickason, Lynn Wood, Horace Mills, Bessie Olivia, and Mary Margaret. Bessie Hoskins married Ulysses Beeler in 1897, and the couple had one child, Betsey, in 1915. Mary Rawls Mills Hoskins died in 1917 in Knoxville, Tennessee.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: World's Fair Grounds (showing the Technology and Lifestyle Center and the International Court of Flags)
abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.
name: unknown

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: William Blount Mansion
abstract: William Blount (who signed the US Constitution and served as the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River) and his wife Mary commissioned this home in 1792. In addition to its impressive size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple led a campaign to preserve Blount Mansion in the early 1920s, and the house became a museum in 1925. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1965.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Market House and Market Street
abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.
name: Thompson, James Edward, 1880-1976

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Me-Na-Wa, a Creek Warrior
abstract: Menawa (meaning The Great Warrior) was chief of the Oakfuskee Creek towns lying on the Tallapoosa River in Alabama. He was widely known as a talented and brutal warrior. A determined opponent of both Creek Chief William MacIntosh and MacIntosh's 1825 Treaty of Indian Springs (which ceded all Creek land in Georgia to the Federal Government), Menawa took part in the 1826 delegation to Washington, DC designed to repudiate the treaty. Although the group failed to have the treaty revoked, Menawa was instrumental in having a provision inserted allowing the Creek to obtain legal patents for their land. He, along with Opothle Yoholo, later fought alongside American troops against the Seminole in Alabama. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826, when Menawa was said to be about sixty years old. The original has since been destroyed by fire.
name: King, Charles Bird, 1785-1862

title: William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow Residence
abstract: Controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow was born in 1805 in Wythe County, Virginia. His zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned to Tennessee in March of 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment (thus sparing Tennessee from Reconstruction) and made great progress toward restoring the State's economic health. He served one term in the US Senate before dying in 1877.

title: David Brian, Juano Hernandez, and Claude Jarman Jr. in "Intruder in the Dust"
abstract: David Brian, Juano Hernandez, and Claude Jarman Jr. in "Intruder in the Dust." The movie is set in rural Mississippi during the 1940s and features Juano Hernandez as Lucas Beauchamp, a black man with a reputation for standing up to whites. When Beauchamp is found standing over a white man's dead body, he is immediately jailed. He insists that he is innocent and asks the town's most prominent lawyer, Gavin Stevens (David Brian), to defend him, but Stevens refuses. The situation changes, however, when a local boy named Chick Mallison (Claude Jarman Jr.) who Beauchamp has helped in the past hears talk of an impending lynching and begs Stevens to change his mind.
name: unknown

title: John T. Whitaker with Unidentified Group
abstract: John Thompson Whitaker was born on January 25, 1906. He earned his A.B. from the University of the South in 1927 and went on to write for the Chattanooga News and the New York Herald Tribune. He eventually became a foreign correspondent and covered the Ethiopian and Spanish Civil Wars before being stationed in Europe during World War II. He wrote three books%3A And Fear Came (1936), Americas to the South (1939), and We Cannot Escape History (1943). He died on September 11, 1946. This photograph may have been taken during one of Whitaker's lecture tours.
name: unknown

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Clarence Brown Directing "The Eagle"
abstract: Based on a Pushkin novel, "The Eagle" stars Rudolph Valentino as a Russian cossack named Vladimir Dubrouvsky. He is one of Catherine the Great's particular favorites, but he will not be kept as a lover and spurns her advances. When Kyrilla Troekouroff steals his lands, he creates a secret identity, "The Black Eagle," and becomes a masked avenger. Although bent on revenge, he falls in love with Troekouroff's daughter, Mascha (Vilma Banky). Mascha, in turn, worships the Eagle but disdains his unmasked identity, her foppish French tutor Monsieur Le Blanc. Dubrouvsky's love for Masha eventually counteracts his desire for revenge against her father, and the couple flee Troekouroff's estate. Although captured by the Czarina's men, Catherine rescinds her orders to execute the Eagle and the pair escape to Paris.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: St. James Hotel
abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

title: Camp Barkley Field Kitchen
abstract: The original caption for this image reads "Our Kitchen in which we ate from just before our Battle with the 157th Inf. March-31-1941. Camp Barkley Texas. Co. K. 158th Inf. 45th Div." The 158th Infantry Regiment began as the First Arizona Volunteer Infantry on September 2, 1865. It was drafted into Federal service during World War I as part of the 40th Division and reassigned to the 45th Division during postwar reorganizations. When a National Emergency was declared on September 16, 1940, the 158th joined the 45th for training at Fort Sill, Oklahoma and Fort Barkley, Texas. They were detached from the 45th in December of 1941 and sent to the Canal Zone for training in jungle warfare before being assigned to the Pacific Theater in early 1943. The unit was scheduled to spearhead the final invasion of Japan, which was subsequently rendered unnecessary by the atomic bomb. The 158th was deactivated and sent home in January of 1946.
name: Hawley, Thomas J, 1914-1999

title: Se-Loc-Ta, a Creek Chief
abstract: Selocta was the son of principal Creek chief Chinnaby, who supported the United States during the Creek War of 1813-1814. Selocta served as a guide and warrior during the conflict, and was eventually instrumental in negotiating the peace settlement. It was in part due to his influence that the Creek later ceded their land on the Alabama River. This print was taken from a portrait painted by Charles Bird King in 1826. The original has since been destroyed by fire.

title: John Gilbert and Greta Garbo in "A Woman of Affairs"
abstract: "A Woman of Affairs" stars Greta Garbo as Diana Merrick, a worldly socialite who has loved Neville 'Nevs' Holderness (John Gilbert) since both were children. Nevs' father disapproves, and sends Nevs to Egypt to work after convincing him not to marry Diana. Two years later, Diana marries another childhood friend, David Furness (Johnny Mack Brown), who later commits suicide in Paris. As a result of the tragedy, Diana is cast out of upper-class English society and embarks on a string of meaningless affairs with men around the world. She eventually returns to England days before Nevs' wedding to Constance (Dorothy Sebastian).

title: Clarence and Marion Brown
abstract: Marion Ruth Spies was born in Ohio on January 22, 1905. She worked as a schoolteacher before moving to Hollywood in search of a more exciting life. She married director Clarence L. Brown on November 10, 1947. He had previously been married to Paul (called Polly) Pratt, Ona Maris, and Alice Joyce. Later in life, Marion Brown became one of the major forces behind the Browns' many contributions to the University of Tennessee. Clarence Brown died on August 17, 1987 and Marion Brown followed on May 10, 1993.

title: The Pickle Mansion
abstract: George Wesley Pickle built the Pickle Mansion (sometimes called Confederate Hall and Fort Sanders Hall) at 1633 Clinch Avenue in 1889. The structure was severely damaged by fire in 2003, but plans have been made to restore it. Pickle himself was a veteran of the Confederate Second Tennessee Infantry and served as Tennessee's Attorney General and Reporter of the State from 1886 to 1902.
name: unknown

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Knox County Court House
abstract: The first Knox County Court House was designed by architect Drury P. Armstrong and constructed in 1842. It was replaced by a more modern building, built in the Queen Anne style, in 1885. Now called the old Knoxville Courthouse, this structure stands on approximately the site of the Federal barracks of James White's Fort. New wings were added to either side of the courthouse in 1919. Visible in the background is the Hotel Andrew Johnson.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Brown on the Set of "Sadie McKee"
abstract: Sadie McKee (Joan Crawford) is a cook's daughter and works a maid for the wealthy Alderson family. Although she flirts with her employer, Mike Alderson (Franchot Tone), she loves her humble boyfriend Tommy Wallace (Gene Raymond). The couple runs away to New York to get married, but before the ceremony Wallace meets a showgirl and deserts McKee. She decides to stay in the city, and gets a job in a nightclub owned by alcoholic millionaire Jack Brennan (Edward Arnold). Brennan is smitten with McKee, who eventually gives up on finding true love and marries Brennan for his money. She is unhappy, however, and leaves him when she finds out that Wallace is in trouble. With Alderson's help, she eventually discovers that he is extremely ill in a hospital. She goes to visit him, and he pair confess their love for each other shortly before Wallace dies.
name: unknown

subject_topical: Motion picture producers and directors--United States

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Joan Crawford and Clark Gable in "Possessed"
abstract: "Possessed" is the story of Marian Martin (Joan Crawford), a factory girl who moves to Manhattan looking for excitement and hoping to trade her life on the assembly line for one more posh. When she meets lawyer Mark Whitney (Clark Gable), she thinks her dreams have come true%3A he is rich and handsome and can buy her the life she dreams of. Unfortunately, he is already married and his political ambitions would be destroyed by a divorce scandal. Thus, Martin becomes his mistress and poses as his ex-wife. When her small town ex-boyfriend Al Manning (Wallace Ford) asks her to marry him, she turns him down and he exposes Whitney's sordid private life. Martin is forced to defend her relationship with Whitney at an election rally, and her story moves the crowd to tears. Relieved, Whitney proposes to Martin, thus fulfilling her ambitions.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Crowds at the World's Fair
abstract: The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982. W. Stuart Evans was the original visionary behind the event, which he intended to attract business to central Knoxville and away from suburban shopping malls. This concept excited Mayor Kyle Testerman, and he appointed banker Jake Butcher to head a committee to investigate the feasibility of such an event. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition, Incorporated (KIEE) was formed in 1976 and Exposition bankers gradually acquired the 67 acre fair site near downtown Knoxville. The fair itself attracted about 11 million visitors, but did not achieve Evans' larger goal, as the event did not spur any major downtown redevelopment.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: St. James Hotel
abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, the St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at the St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.
name: unknown

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Hotel Farragut
abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, the Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay and Clinch (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. The Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.
name: unknown

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
collection_title: University of Tennessee Photograph and Slide Collection
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Students in Strong Hall
abstract: Sophronia Strong Hall (known colloquially as "Sophie's") was built in 1925 when the University found itself in need of a larger women's dormitory. Benjamin Rush Strong (1848-1915) had left the University $30,000 in his will for the purpose on the condition that the resulting building be named after his mother, Sophronia (Marrs) Strong, and that a wildflower garden be planted every spring in her memory. Several wings were added in the 1950s, each named after one of the first co-eds to attend the University. Sophronia Strong's ghost was said to watch over the Hall's residents, appearing as a lady dressed in white on her birthday (February 17) and perpetrating various harmless pranks. The last residents of the hall moved out after the 2008 Spring Semester and the building was put to other uses.

title: Mary Cora de Garmo Bryan
abstract: Portrait of Mary Cora de Garmo (1891-1986) taken at her wedding to Charles W. Bryan (1890-1966) on May 9, 1920. Born on August 28, 1891, Mary was the first child of Frank and Mary Eloise (Donnell) de Garmo. She earned her A.B. (1912) and M.A. (1913) degrees at Washington College and eventually obtained a Ph.D from Cornell University (1931). During her career as a nutritionist, she taught at several educational institutions, edited the "Journal of Home Economics," wrote four books, helped to develop the national school lunch program, and served in a variety of professional organizations. She died in Illinois on May 12, 1986.

repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Knoxville High School
abstract: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J.Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. It was intended to provide a cultural education and enjoyed a reputation as one of the South's best schools. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s, and now houses a number of educational programs including adult education, the adult high school, GED testing, and continuing education.

rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
title: Oakwood Mansion
abstract: Charles J. McClung built Oakwood Mansion for his son, Matthew McClung, in 1870. The house changed hands in 1873, when it became home to Matthew's sister Lucy and her husband, Jacob Lytton Thomas. The home was then located at the outskirts of town, allowing Thomas to farm and raise livestock. Railroad contractor Henry H. Thrasher purchased the house in about 1905 and remodeled it completely, adding porches, columns, and the brick exterior. He sold it in the late 1920s to a group of physicians, who renamed it the Howard-Henderson Hospital. It was briefly known as the Acuff Clinic before becoming the Kingston Pike Motel in the late 1950s. When that enterprise failed, the structure was remodeled and reopened as the Kingston Pike Nursing Home. It continued in this capacity until the early 1990s. It was home to a number of businesses, including a beauty parlor and a restaurant, before Sam Furrow purchased it in 1999. The structure currently serves as office space for a number of enterprises.
name: unknown
